qas.question: When did glassworkers begin to consider their products fine art?
What type of glass did many Art Nouveau artists use?
When did mass production of glass art begin?
What early civilization made cameo glass?
What famous lampmaker used factory production?
When did glassworkers begin to consider their products neo-classical?
What type of glass did many specialists use?
When did mass production of lamps begin?
What early civilization made colored vases?

context: From the 19th century, there was a revival in many ancient glass-making techniques including <b7_0>cameo glass<b7_0/>, achieved for the first time since the <a4_0><b9_0>Roman Empire<b9_0/><a4_0/> and initially mostly used for pieces in a neo-classical style. The Art Nouveau movement made great use of glass, with René Lalique, Émile Gallé, and Daum of Nancy producing colored vases and similar pieces, often in <a2_0>cameo glass<a2_0/>, and also using luster techniques. <a0_0><b5_0>Louis Comfort Tiffany<b5_0/><a0_0/> in America specialized in stained glass, both secular and religious, and his famous lamps. The <a3_0><b8_0>early 20th-century<b8_0/><a3_0/> saw the large-scale factory production of glass art by firms such as Waterford and Lalique. From about <a1_0><b6_0>1960<b6_0/><a1_0/> onwards there have been an increasing number of small studios hand-producing glass artworks, and glass artists began to class themselves as in effect sculptors working in glass, and their works as part fine arts.
